results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.

results.title: On the job
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Sponsored by the National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee these seven films are designed to encourage aboriginal job seekers and illustrate some of the employment opportunities available.

results.title: We did it!: Rockhampton and Mackay
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight, National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”
Shows Aboriginal people at work in Rockhampton and Mackay, talking about how they got their jobs, what they like about them and giving tips for other job seekers. Includes an employment officer, a secretary, an apprentice picutre framer and a TAFE field officer.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: We did it!: Western Australia
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight, National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
Shows Aboriginal people in Western Australia talking about how they got their jobs, what they like about them and giving tips for other job seekers. Includes a student enrolled nurse, a teacher’s aide, a beautician, a horticulturalist and a park ranger.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Women of Utopia
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
With jokes and good humour, the Aboriginal women of Utopia cattle station show how they make their beautiful and exotic batik fabrics. Some of the women featured are Emily Ngwarai, Gloria Pitjara, Rosie Kunoth and Myrtle Pitjara. Also shows gathering/hunting of food and the cooking of it. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: A Ticket to ride
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
Explores the lives of four Aboriginal people, two women and two men, who have battled to attain high career achievements and top jobs in Australia. Features Wesley Lanhupuy, MLA Arnhem Land, N.T., Pat O’Shane, Secretary of N.S.W. Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs, Ernie Bridge, MLA Kimberley, W.A. and Marcia Langton, BA, 1st Class Hons, ANU.

results.title: Narritjin Maymuru
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Narritjin Maymuru is a respected aboriginal artist. This series of films profiles the man and his work, as well as looking at the traditional way of life he and his family follow at Djarrakpi near Yirrkala in the Northern Territory. Photography is by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia

group_works.title: At the canoe camp

results.title: Narritjin in Canberra
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
The film shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their ANU studio and later an exhibition of their work. In 1978 Narritjin Maymuru and his son Banapana were awarded fellowships as Visiting Artists to the Faculty of Arts at the Australian National University in Canberra. This program shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their A.N.U. studio. With anthropologist Howard Morphy, Narritjin conducts a seminar session for anthropology students. He explains his technique of bark painting and discusses some of the meanings behind the paintings. At the end of their stay in Canberra, Narritjin and Banapana hold an exhibition of their Manggalili art.
